Bouteille verte, 75 cl, via Importations Privées Bièropholie, savourée le 1er mars 2008; il : léger orangé, voilée, matière en suspension, mousse blanche formée de bulles plutôt grosses, dentelle; nez : fruitée tropicale, levure, légèrement épicée (un peu de poivre), léger floral; bouche : crémeuse, fruitée, légèrement épicées (un peu de poivre), un peu de levure, rafraîchissante, un peu de lime, finale un peu sèche mais fruitée avec présence de levure, légère astringence, légèrement sucrée, très légèrement amère, corps moyen, peu carbonatée; en résumé : bien aimé
Pours gold with a slight haze.  Thick white head and saison like aroma.  Matter of fact this beer shares many similarities to a saison.  Fruits, straw, and hops with a thin mouth-feel.

Bottle. Aroma of an IPA? Malt with floral hop anyway. Light orange gold color with a hefty white head doing a little lacing. Medium to full bodied with creamy carbonation. The flavor is malt, floral hop, light stone fruits, and cardamom and/or clove. Very tasty. The finish is dry, though sweet fruit notes lurk, and there is delightful low level bitter. Tastes wonderful.
Wow!!1!1 Hoppy, golden goodness. Sweet, with hints of apple cider. Really yum! On tap at Burp Castle!!!

Bouteille 750ml. De couleur orangée et voilée. Nez de levures fruitées (agrumes, pêche, léger de poires, notes de mangues), moyennement malté de sucre bonbon et avec des notes de pain, de houblon herbeux et dépices (traces de poivre). Moyennement ronde en bouche avec un pétillement moyen et une texture moyennement crémeuse. Goût de levures fruitées aux faibles notes sûres (agrumes, moyen de poires, léger de pêche, traces de pommes) avec des notes épicées (notes de clou de girofle et traces de coriandre) lors de lentrée en bouche auquel se rajoute un goût malté de sucre bonbon accompagné de notes de pain et des traces de biscuits au miel puis en finale lon retrouve un goût moyennement amer de levures aux notes épicées (poivre) et asséchantes, léger de houblon herbeux et dalcool doux. UPDATED: FEB 17, 2008 Bright hazy orange with a huge creamy & lacing white head. Very strong aroma of tropical fruits, white pepper, little cloves, orange, peaches and fresh grounded malt. No traces of that 8.5%, neither in mouth. Very smooth and pleasant, with a  firm but very balanced hoppiness leading to a grassy dry end.

Cloudy orange, nice sized white head. Spicy, clean, soapy, slightly fruity aroma. Nicely full bodied. Mellow citrus - lemon, lime, mango, - mixes with a heavy white eine flavor. Nice herbal notes dry it out at the finish.

750ml bottle from Holiday Wine Cellar. Creates a large buxom white foam on top of a burnt gold hue. The nose is a mild serving of yeast and grainy malt but overall is very subtle and calm. The flavor is astringent with a bold metallic taste and notice of grain and malt. Not that flavorful, but the lively carbonation is enough to keep me drinking the remainder of the bottle.

Apricot color; small head.  Amber malt aroma and taste, with nice amount of candy sugar and flavors of powder sugar, subtle cardamon and cloves, citrus, burnt caramel.  Ive had this a few times in the bottle and on tap in Philadelphia and always find it right up there with the smoothest tripels.
Hazy yellow, heavy sediment. Decent foamy head and heavy lacing. Yeast, cloves, mild spice, bananas, and warm fresh bread are the prominent flavors. Alcohol is well hidden.  Soft bodied.
Pours a very dense gold with quite a bit of white head that quickly dissipates to a bit of lace. A fairly thick medium body. The aroma is pretty weak. Flavor is yeast and cloves. Fairly mild tripel.
Pours  a dense gold with a lasting white head and lace. Medium body with a pronounced sweet flavor balance.

750 mL bottle. Pours cloudy orange with nice white head. The aroma is quite spicy with plenty of yeast notes, maybe some grass and orange. The flavor has an assertive spicy yeast character, under which lies a soft, honeyish malt character. Banana and clove are minimal, but subtle, nondescript spices and fruits bounce around. The finish is slightly dry and zesty. This is a pretty good beer.

Bottle from Bitter Virtue. Great combination of peachy summery fruit and zesty hop aroma with some spicy yeast in the background. Soft fruity sweet malts with a decent level of bitterness and a nice tangy finish. Smooth creamy body. Lovely beer and didnt seem to suffer from all the yeast that was kicked up when it was opened.

Bottle. Pours a nice golden yellow body with nice head. Aroma is yeast, earthy, esters. Flavor was a surprise compared to the typical tripel smell. Nice earthy body and very subtle spices that made the taste and body very smooth and quaffable. A world class tripel.

75 cL bottle. Pours slight hazy, small flaoties and a collapsing white head. Classic belgian aroma of spicy yeast, fruity, caramel malt and a whiff of coriander. Flavour is softly sweet and a caramel malty. Has a very soft yeast note of spices and a mild coriander note. Extremely soft, smooth and wellbalanced. More floral hoppy than other belgian triples, refreshing.
Bottle. Courtesy of yespr. Pours a bit hazy orange colour. Fruity soft alco bitter aroma. Fruity, softly spiced, toasty and easty flavour. Bitter spiced finish.

The beer pours from the 750ml bottle a hazy golden amber with a bit of orange shading, head is creamy white and piles high on the body, lace forms a nice concealing sheet. Nose has a candy sweet aroma, fruity, peaches comes to mind, a bit astringent, soapy, start has a decent sweet malt presence, slight bitterness along with the tartness, moderate in feel. Finish has unrelenting acidity, sour and sweet continues, hops understated, very dry, a drinkable beer, 8.4 percent ABV, does leave an alcohol bitterness and a bit of a warming sensation.

Pears, peaches,  lemons, yeast, must and dusty hops in the aroma; quite medicinal and pheoneic, initially, hot alcohol and acidic fruitiness follows with bready maltiness; dryish, tart, and somewhat bitter finish. Muted spices and balanced palate mkes this a good tripel.

wonderful wonderful what a flavorful beer.  Just poured from the tap at the Delerium Tremens... Slightly cloudy with rich malt and ester profile.  It is beauty in a glass.  The rich character of this beer stay swith you from start to finish.  Sweet and spicy the beer is rich and warming with candy notes and fruity notes that make the depth of this beer.  A must try for this small artisnal brewery.

Bomber on sale at Consumers.  Gotta love getting a closeout price on a 90+ brew.  Pours a cloudy amber like most Belgians, white head, citrusy aroma.  Not overly sweet, but very smooth.  Boy am I glad I got 2 bombers on sale.
75 cl. bottle. Golden, hazy, a minimal white head. Medium body, oily feel and soft carbonation. Medium sweetness and bitterness.Good balance.

Draft at Zeno’s.  Cloudy orange and pink colored body with a white filmy head.  Perfumy, soapy floral nose, heavy on the soapy, floral spices and yeasty esters.  Crisp palate up front, with more of a wet paper character over the middle, with near-sour grain flavors and some floral, yeast, spicy notes in the finish.

On draft at Zenos.  Pours a hazy orange caramel with a medium white head.  Aroma of apricot,orange peel and tangerine with a hint of lemon.  Taste is pleasantly sweet and sour with hints of apricot, papaya, orange peel, lemon with a spicy all around feel.  Very nice.

Aroma is spicy, full of complex grains and some bubblegum.  This amber pour has light lacing and tastes like your standard full bodied triple with notes of spice.  It was smooth and very drinkable.  It slightly warmed as it went down.
Cask @ Delirium Cafe. Pale gold with a foamy white head. Standard Belgian tripel, yeasty hops, spice and citrus in the nose with a taste to match. Salty finish. Not as good as expected.

UPDATED: AUG 29, 2010 Flaske. SUperlækker trippel, med lidt mere bid end normalt. God humle der giver biddet men stadig lækkert afbalanceret. Bare lækker til endnu en ydmygelse af Bif :) Gensmagt. og hevet den en smule op. Er virkelig en lækker trippel med masser af friskhed. Super til at omvende folk til øl.

750 ml.  Cloudy orange/amber with a thin off-white head.  Some yeast floaties and spotty lacing.  Floral, honey and mild citrusy aromas over cookie/caramel malts.  A bit of pepper/spice as well.  Smooth light caramel malt and citrus flavors with a restrained tinge of hop and spice.  A bit on the light side palatewise I thought, with little carbonation and a slightly watery finish. Overall though, a fairly decent tripel.

750 ml in Westmalle glass.  Hazy orange with orange-tinted head and lace.  Orangey aroma.  Honey-orange flavor with tobacco bitterness and somewhat hoppy finish.  Nice complex flavors.  Very full-bodied for the style, I think.  Fairly low carbonation.   Very good.
Nice fruity taste. Light but with that lovely yeast taste you get from a triple. A really nice beer and perfect for football season.

A hazy amber ale with a thick off white head. Aroma of fruity esters, sweet bananas, yeast and herbs. In mouth, a nice sweet candy sugar with light herbal hops, very present, coriander, oranges, and nice alcohol in final.
Its got a sharp taste of frutis and the malts are very robust. I find that one very good for the style and flavors of a Belgium beer.

The aroma is yeasty, with corn malt, and some light fruitiness. The appearance is cloudy amber with a typical head for the style. The flavor is bitter and like the aroma. The palate is average for the style. Overall a decent beer but nothing special.

Van tvat in the Delirium Cafe. As the Estivale, but more so. Bittersweet, fruitily hopped Tripel with a pithy blast of grapefruit. Estery Jelly Tot citrus and mellow spice. Witbier hazy with creamy suds and lace. Ridiculously quenching for the strength. Well-rounded and hoppy. Approaching greatness. One to resample bottled.

golden amber with a nice frothy head leaving some sticky lacing. nice aromas of spices and yeast with a light sweetness. taste is well balanced with nice maltyness and caramel notes that balance out the minor hop bitterness.

Bottle 75 cl. Large and light creamy like head that mostly diminished. Good display of lacework. Hazy amber color. Aroma of yeast, spice, fruit, caramel, citrus and light hoppy notes as well. Quit full bodied with an average carbonation and light dry texture. Maybe a hint of alcohol. Well balanced sweet and bitter flavor. Light spicy and sweet finish. Quit nice Triple.
ottima intensità olfattiva media frizzanterzza corpo strutturato buon equilibrio gustativo persistenza lunga

On tap @ festival Hotton. Golden color with white head. Aroma of (citrus) fruits, little spices, some malts. Medium to full body. Tasted of the same with a warm alocholic touch,  fruits and spice,  with hops in the aftertaste. Very nice flavor. 
For me the best of this brewery !

This is a fairly good triple. Aroma is very light and not very noticeable. There is something missing here though - its not quite as well-rounded as it could be and the alcohol is a bit too prominent.

I know I have a bottle of this somewhere, but I decided to try it on draft at Isaac Newtons.  Golden color with a medium, but lasting white head.  Aroma is bready and sweet with some orange and spice in the nose.  Flavor is really nice with some sweet breadiness, orange, caramel, spice and just a bit of hop flavor .  Nice tripel!!

On tap at the brickstore.  Pours a cloudy golden color with a big white head that dissipates and leaves a decent lacing down the glass.  Big malt profile gives this one some body.  Nice spice and citrus flavors as well.  A faint banana flavor in there too.  Slight sweetness on the finish.

UPDATED: APR 8, 2008 Poured a golden yellow color with a nice thick white head that left good lacing. It smelled of citrus fruits, spices, and some malts as well. It tasted of the same with the fruits and spice, but had a little sourness in there too. A good sticky mouthfeel that finished clean and crisp with hops in the aftertaste. Had a really nice flavor. Thanks to mgumby and solan for sharing this.
Københavnske Øldage 07. Light straw and a nice, creamy head. The aroma has notes of fruit and citrus and the flavour has sweetness, citrus, fruit, malt and the body is full and harmonic. 18/29

Pours a a golden yellow with a medium white head.  Smells of spice, a little caramel, and citrus fruit.  The taste is even slightly sour with a good spice character to it.  A little bit fruity, but nothing over the top.  Pretty crisp and refreshing tripel.  Finishes clean, with a nice funky aftertaste.  Good flavor in this beer.
Yeasty aroma, spicy and sour.  pours blonde with a thick white head.    Hints of sourness with a crispy hop flavor.  Great tripel!
Nice appearance.  Golden color, good lacing and carbonation.  Sour, vanilla flavor, nice tripel.

Draft-poured a cloudy ayellow hue wiht a thick white hea.d .Aroma wasaix of banana and corriandor. Flavor had a good balance between sweet fruit notes and spice notes. Alcohol waswarming in the finish. Carbonation was mild.

750 ml bottle.  Rich golden colur, creamy white head.  Aroma is quite lovely, honey and apricot top notes over a light lean maltiness.  A touch of earthydusty character behind the yeasty spiciness.  Warming brings up a bit of clove and sweet melon, white grapes and a light berryish note as well.  Flavour shows a prickle of white pepper and berries with a soft sweetness up front.  Herbal/earthy notes in the middle and a dry finish.  Quite hoppy on the back which accentuates the beers dryness.  Tasty and elegant brew.  Lightly bready on the back.

Pours dark golden with a mostly receding white head. Aroma of apples, banana, cloves, and honey. Taste is sweet and fruity, with a mix of fruity apple and pineapple esters mixed with apple phenolics. Mouthfeel is full bodied, slightly sticky with full carbonation. Enjoyable, but not what I consider a top caliber tripel.
Robe blonde voilée surmontée dune mousse qui sestompe. Arômes de levures et dagrumes. Saveurs de malt, de sucre, de levures et dalcool.

I had this one on tap at Brouwers in Seattle for their Belgian beer month.  This strong ale was easy to drink but left a bitter aftertaste.  Appearance is cloudy yellow and had head that went away quickly.  Lacing was medium to light.  Aroma was yeasty,  Flavor was a bit wheaty and sweet.  Nice representation of the style

Mondial de la bière 07. Couleur or-jaune voilée, mousse moyenne qui trace bien le verre. Arôme doux complexe dépices, de levure, floral. Goût doux, équilibré, légèrement houblonné, épicé. Corps moyen à plein, effervescence moyenne. Bon.
Vootas gf jenna had this in the delirium cafe, and i rated it 3.7 then forgot to write down any notes.
Bu au Mondial 07. Blonde mi brumeuse, petit collet. Arome doux dherbe malté et houblonneux. Goût de malte épicé crèmeuse avec des fruits doux.

On draught on 9/11/06 at Delirium Cafe, Brussels.  Presented in a slander weizen-esque glass with the La Rulles script on it.  Wait i minute, what are those hops doing in my triple?  Why theyre enticing me!  Beautiful marriage of yeasty esters, citrusy hop bitterness and malty goodness.  Visted the brewery 2 days later and learned that they get their yeast from Orval and use American hops.  Belgian American Triple Pale Ale?  Whatever, its tasty.
Pours a cloudy orange with a nice white head.  The aroma has hints of grass, orange, wheat, and fruit.  Has a sweet flavor with fruity notes, herb, and malt.

Could smell the wheat immediately. Pours a blanket white, very creamy head that subsides with haste. Reminiscent of Saison Dupont with strong tastes of grain and alcohol. Hints of coriander with a slight metallic after taste. I get "happy mouth" syndrome after drinking this beer.

Bottle @ Københavnske Øldage 2007 in Copenhagen. Unclear dark pale golden color with a average frothy good lacing mostly lasting off-white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy yeasty, toffee, sweet malt. Initial flavor is moderate to heavy sweet. finish flavor is moderate to heavy sweet, light to moderate bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium to full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft, finish feel is light alcoholic. ;o)

Brux 07. Pours a hazy dark golden with a small head. Heavy sweetness with a light bitterness. Aromas of candis. Hoppy aromas of flowers and perfume. Also an average alcohol touch with hints of coriander. Full bodied. Medium carbonation with a dry finish. Wheaty.

750ml bottle from Kingdom Liquors Brandon, Fl. Pours a hazy golden orange with a one finger lasting head that leaves good lacing. Aroma is very yeasty and full of sweet malt and I think American Amarillo hops. The taste has light bready notes with hints of citrus, honey, and yeasty spice. Medium mouthfeel with a mild bitterness but lots of hop flavor. A very unique and delicious Tripel.
Pours a hazy gold. Aroma was citrusy with hints of hops. Taste was honey with hints of spice.

Draft at Delirium Café in Brussels

Poured into a tall logo Hefe looking glass, the beer appeared a cloudy golden orange with a tall whipped white head. In the aroma and flavor, the yeast bade a bold statement;  it was quite fruity with big phenol esters, doughy with life-size spicy clove, black pepper, red apple and banana. The palate was oily and slick.  I really did enjoy this beer, twice; and it was oddly the best beer that Delirium Café had on its draft lineup?

Tons of dark, sandy sediment can be found in the hazy, bronzed-orange body of this beer under a fluffy head which settles to spittles. Too-heavy alcohol is the only fault to a yeasty aroma with violets and a white wine tang. Smooth in the mouth finishing dry. My numbers continue but my words do not, as I put down my pen and choose to enjoy this beer rather than continue writing.

750 mL bottle purchased at Coaltrain Wine and Liquor.  Pours hazy orange with an average creamy off-white head, mostly lasting, good lacing.  Aroma is average malt (bread, straw, meal), average hops (grass, herbs), heavy yeast (dough, earth) with notes of banana and honey.  Full bodied, creamy texture, soft carbonation and a creamy finish.  Moderate sweetness, acidity and bitterness; earthy wheat yeast flavor and bread malts.
750ml - Liquid gold under fleeting dark tan head.  Cloudy.  malt and berries on nose.  Bananas, berries and malt on palate.  Representative.
Delirium Cafe Brussels: cirus, yeast, a pleasure to drink, pretty good but not to the level as some others I had that day.
Hazy orange-amber body with a large frothy white head. Sweet fruity spiced aroma with a yeasty background. Sweet sugary caramel and fruity flavor with some light yeast in the background.
Hazy golden body with sediment, frothy white head.  Sweet grassy aroma.  Caramel and citrus flavour.

hazy peach/orange color with suspended particles and a medium sized but quickly diminishing head.  aroma is very hoppy and citrusy.  flavor is full of caramel and citrus.  very much like a biere de garde.  nice but not a tripel to me.  thin bodied.  hint of alcohol in aftertaste.  hints of spices.

On tap @ Delirium. An excellent tripel that remains underrated. Golden color with a big, lasting head. Heavy hops in the nose and nicely bitter flavor, which also has some wheaty elements. Some orange and spices, but understated and the hops are in control. Highly recommended for all fans of the style.

This is a very tasty beer.  Spicy hot aromas leap out at you, nearly overtaking the more subtle hints of coriander and citrus.  Very refreshing, not overly cloying, and drinkable despite the relatively high alcohol.  Again, a wonderfully spicy hoppiness permeates this one, start to finish, and is really quite surprising.  One that you can find on draft -- and well worth the search, in my opinion, as it is so much livelier off a good tap than its sibling bottle version (which lacks for nothing else).

UPDATED: JAN 29, 2016 (Draught at Akkurat, Stockholm, 3 March 2007) Dark amber colour, slightly cloudy, with brief white head. Very spicy, fruity nose with citrus and yeasty notes. Fruity, spicy taste with notes of yeast, orange peel, grapefruit, clove and lots of spicy hops in a long finish. Lovely! (7/3/8/4/16=3.8) Rerate: (Bottle, 29 Jan 2016) Golden amber colour, cloudy, with frothy white head. Fruity, malty nose with notes of orange, ginger, lemon peel, coriander and honey. Malty, spicy taste with orange, ginger, honey, coriander, lemon peel and a balanced grassy/floral bitterness in the finish. More than medium body, with a touch of sweetness. Solid and well made tripel, quite spicy and complex. Very nice.

Draught at Akkurat, Stockholm. Hazy dark golden , low white foam. Nice oily aroma of orangey and leafy hops with estery undertones. Nice interplay between juicy fruity malts and leafy and grassy hops in the flavour. Aromatic finish of flowers, Seville oranges with dryish undertones of wet grass.

(750ml bottle) Purchased through the Bieropholie Private imports. Pours a lasting white webbing of head atop an amber, tiny sediment-filled body. Nose of very orangy citrus hops, cream and tin. Flavour is mildly hoppy tart, honey lager and medicinal syrup. Thin bitter finish - not what I expected. I wanted more malt and more oily texture.

Pours a hazey, slighty tawnied honey color w/ a full, semi creamy froth. Aroma is slightly skunky w/ malted banana spice and citrus rind. Medium nectar w/ ample residual effers creating a soft and creamy texture. This brew lives up to its genre. Strongly flavored w/ big banana malts. I catch a glimpse of citrus rind hops, clove spice, vanilla, banana gum , and honeycomb. Finish is long on flavor and bittered w/ peach pit. A nice specimen.

The 25.4 ounce bottle poured a slightly hazy amber-orange colored beverage with an average sized white creamy head that was mostly diminishing but left good lacing on the glass. Because it is bottle conditioned, there were also some small particles floating about. The aroma was sweet, fruity and spicy with notes of grape, pear, coriander and pepper. The body was medium with lively but soft carbonation and a smooth creamy texture. The flavors start off lightly sweet with the sweetness gradually replaced with a light acidic tartness through the long finish. There is also a nice alcohol warmth at the end.

Pours a three-finger smooth cream head that fades slowly to a thin layer leaving some lace.  Almost cloudy amber color.  Malty, alcohol nose.  Strong carbonation and medium bodied. Starts semi-sweet, high ABV is here, dry finish $8.99 for a 750ml bottle from Tullys Beer & Wine Wells, Me.

Bottle, August 2005. Hazy gold, good white head and moderate condition. Muted but insistent fruity maltiness in the nose, quite hoppy at first in the mouth with a building sweet spicy maltiness and alcohol developing before dominating in the finish.

pours with an nice off white head, bit of  lingering lace, balanced - nice hop, sweetness offset with hop and yeast. slightly hazy yellow gold. nice body and carbonation. decent beer. had it on draft at Bodega downtown La Crosse, Wis.
Bottle.  Aroma was of yeast and a light spice.  Flavor about the same; a nicemalt presence.  Creamy mouthfeel.  Bitter finish.  Pretty good for style.

Bottle shared in late November with the crew, thanks R.  Dark yellow, thick white head.  Nice aroma of yeast, bread, light malt, light spice.  Really nice taste, yeast, strong malt, some honey sweetness.  Very nice, bitter finish.  Very good.
Sweet, yeasty, substantial mouthfeel.  A bit of spice, with a nice amount of hops as well.  Very good standard Belgian Triple.

bottle. slightly hazy golden/copper pour with creamy head and nice lacing throuhout.  This beer gets better as it warms.  Aroma is very hoppy with citrus smoothed out a bit with yeast and spice.  alocohol very present.  tart initially.  light and creamy.  sweet yeast, spice and fruit.  big bitter finish.

A hazy orange beer with a thick lazing white head. The aroma is sweet with strong notes of fruit especially peaches, but also notes of green grapes, malt, prunes, over ripe fruits, wood, malt, and alcohol. The flavor is very sweet with strong notes of over ripe fruits, both oranges and peaches, as well as some cloves, malt, wood, and alcohol. Leading to a slightly acidic and fruity end.

Bottle. Well carbonated hazy orange body with a medium-sized fluffy white head. Cheesy metallic yeastiness in the aroma along with a bit of cereal. Nice sweet cereal flavour, pears, other fruits, and some butterscotch. Faint alcohol. Pretty good.
Hazy golden ale.  Spicy pepper, yeast aroma.  Pepper taste somewhat watery, light body.

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry, biegaman, mds, Radek Kliber, tupalev & the rest of the gang -- my bottle courtesy of Secret Santa. Pours a cloudy yellow-orange with sediment and an average size lasting white head. Sweet aroma of Belgian yeast, spices and sweet malt -- nice! Flavour of yeast, sweet malt, fruit, spices, hops, sugar and a light bitter finish. Alcohol pretty well hidden. Medium bodied. Pretty good.

Bottle (750ml).  Shared with blankboy, biegaman, mds, Radek Kliber, tupalev and others, blankboys bottle.  Poured cloudy orange-yellow with an average frothy white head.  Dry, yeasty, sweet malt, spicy, nicely complex.  Tastes pretty much the same, just fruitier, I get pears and apples, with some bitter yeast in the finish.  Pretty standard tripel body - soft, on the light side, somewhat alcoholic and soft - nice finish.
On tap at Uber a while ago...Slightly cloudy golden. Subtle belgian yeast taste with good sweetness. Hints of pineapple.

Bottled.  A clear orange coloured beer with a large off-white head which dissipates all too quickly.  The aroma is yeast, spicy and peppery.  The taste is yeasty and spicy.  The hops come through reeally nicely though with some orange flavours.  Clean tasting and good alcohol levels.  A classy tripel.

Pours a darkish blonde, only slightly hazy.  Moderate foamy head that lingers.  Scent is bready, with candied malt and a marked alcohol sharpness.  The flavor is quite nice.  Overall, its clean and fresh, and very sweet.  As in the nose, the flavor is noticeably alcoholic.  Mouthfeel is foamy and a bit prickly, as a tripel should be.  The finish is drier than the flavor, with the same amount of warmth.  This beer isnt as complex as the best of the style, but its nice to drink.  Id definitely do it again.

Pours a nice amber with a tall, sticky cream head that sticks to the glass thickly. Heavily perfumed with fruits and phenols, theres even a light unroasted nuttiness in there as well. Fairly sweet body and a bit of heat in there from the alcohol.

Pours amber into a tulip.  Tan conglomerate head leaves chunky lacing as it recedes.  Bread, earth and hay aromas.  Medium bodied, with front-to-back sweet caramel turning to a dry, slightly bitter lasting finish.

Draught - Bruxellensis Festival.  Hazy gold, thin off white head.  Hoppy aroma.  Tangerine flavours.  Good tripel, ticks all the boxes, tangerine is good.  Never gets overly sweet, some dryness on end.
looks cloudy golden frothy head. smells like sweat grass and honey. tastes the same the alcohol isnt hidden too well for only 8.4% not too bad not great.

Bottle.  Pours solid cheddar with a nice head and lacing.  Aroma is solid bread with slight orange.  Flavor is a light orange/peach yeast.  Full and coating on the tongue, with a tingling that makes the taste buds giggle with delight.  Best drunk over a game of Mexican Train in Wichita, KS.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Same as the last few folks, tap at Delirium. Very nice easy drinking triple with a nice dry citrus taste and a hint of honey. Pours very cloudy with a white head.

On tap at the Delirium Cafe, Brussels.: Poured couldy yellow with a medium white head. Slight bubblegum in the nose and what seems to me to be spearmint. Mild mint in the flavor also. Mild sweetness up front and a pretty bitter finish. Decent.

UPDATED: MAR 16, 2010 (Draught at Delirium Cafe, Brussels) Pours golden/yellow. slightly hazy with a white head. Smells yeast, pine, kiwi, honey, and marzipan. Some spices. Nutmeg. Liquorice and salt. The taste is salty with honey, and a peppery feeling. Bitter and a bit sour finish. Earthy. Medium body. A really nice trippel. 7/3/7/3/14. Rerate: (Bottle) Pours hazy yellow golden with a medium head. The aroma is of bready and cracker-like malt with band aid/clove-like phenols. Esters bring notes of banana, watermelon and tropical, yellow fruits. Undertones of citrus, perfume and coriander. The flavour is light sweet and light to medium bitter. Spicy, floral and fruity. The mouthfeel is juicy, yet slim with perfect carbonation. Spicy and light fruity finish. Medium bodied. Love!

Bottle at the Brickskeller.
I really liked this beer.  I am begining to think abbey tripels might be my favorite flavor.  Nothing to wierd and spicey about them like some of the trappist stuff, but light and wonderful.
This beer in particular was a nice loking beer with a big fluffy head.  A very nice floral, citrusy aroma.  And a wonderful floral, citrus, hoppy, grassy, sweet spiced flavor.
Bottle sampled with Stegosaurus. Pours cloudy golden with a white head. Aroma of citrus, spices, and alcohol. The flavor is spices, citrus, and hoppy bitter (but well balanced).
nothing spectacular.  not a lot of flavor.  some fruit in aroma, a little hops.  no alcohol flavor, but not much candy sugar at all (super not american tripel).

Hazy, dull orange-straw body with a soft, downy white head and sagging lace. Nicely fragrant aroma of orange and rose petal esters, light spice, and sweet bread. Rich and floral, full flavor of chamomile and coriander with some warming menthol and clove phenols plus alcohol in the finish. Moderately bitter and slightly numbing with a semi-dry mouthfeel. A nice, distinct tripel overall.

Awesome triple, cloudy golden appearance, off-white head with great lacing around the glass, spicy nose full of citrus, grapefruit & yeast, full-bodied, very drinkable, smooth body & flavors, notes of lemongrass in the flavors along with citrusy hops & bread, very smooth finish with more spicy hops & delicate malt

Thanks to Degarth for this one.  Pours deep coppery/dark straw colored with 2-finger off-white head.  Aroma of floral spices, some hopcit, some yeasty cobwebby malts.  The flavor is spicy and floral, with a solid hop and citrus presence backed up well by the malt.  Well balanced and very enjoyable.

UPDATED: SEP 24, 2006 Golden body with a light red tint, duickly diminishing white head.  Typical Belgian aroma, yeast and light fruits are most present.  Tast is very interesting, a combination of a Belgian and an IPA.  Belgian yeast dominate, but not without a heavy hop accent.  Ending is warming with some wheat presence.

Bottle from Lubière: Poured a light yellow ale with a huge foamy white head with perfect retention. Aroma of floral malt with grassy hops and light spices. Taste is refreshing with some grassy and floral malt, some fruit sweetness and light spicy finish. Body is just above average and alcohol is well hidden. This beer would have gained by not being so filtered IMO. Still a great triple and a very good thirst quencher.

(05.17.06) One pint 9.4 oz green bottle from DiCarlos, Mundelein, IL. 8.4% ABV.  Unfiltered, unpasteurized, bottle conditioned. Poured hazy orange with large white head. Some white particulates. Soft carbonation. Fruity sweet malt aroma. Medium bodied tripel that starts with light malt sweetness and intense fruity spicy flavors. Some sharpness (carbonation) in the mouth. Finished with light fruity and spice flavors.  Yum. Smooth, rich and complex flavor character, full of fruit and spice.

On tap.Pours a clear, pale straw yellow with plenty of streaming bubbles that form very little head. Aroma suggests grassy hops and some candy sugar. Odd bubble-gum flavor with some spicy but not particularly bitter hops. Thin, bubbly palate. Why folks serve otherwise bottle-conditioned beers out of standard kegs is a mystery to me. For that matter, its also a mystery why brewers that should know better put keg versions of their bottle-conditioned beers on the market. My guess is this beer would have been much, much better served in bottle form.

Big banana nose.  Hazy, chicken soup color with a gritty head.  Cool tap handle.  Drier than the aroma would suggest.  A bit briney, strange phenols whisper "Silly Putty".  Mercifully quick, pasty finish with some fruit.  Drink cold.

UPDATED: APR 10, 2008 In short: An amazingly drinkable smooth yeasty blonde ale.  Fluffy a bit wild with milky fruity notes.  Far from intense but oh so satisfying.
How: Bottle 750ml, about 6 months old.
The look: Cloudy golden body with lots of yeast particles and a medium white head
In long: Amazing yeast profile.  Fluffy body, meringue, light grapefruit, whip cream, some bananas, some ice cream.  Light tartness.  Something wild about the beer, not funky but still wilder than most Saisons.  Very little hops presence.  No alcohol at all, drinks itself like a 5% witbier.  Parts of it remind me of their Estivalle on steroids without the hops of the Estivalle.  This is not an intense beer, it is a very smooth, subtle and extremely pleasant beer.  Dont expect a classic tripel, this is a different beast.  After trying their excelletn Rulles Estivale I was expecting the Cadillac of Abbey Tripels but ended-up getting a custom Rolls-Royce instead!!!
This hazy gold color triple, has sweet spicy flavors and a floral aroma. It has a long lasting head.  The nice bitter finish is just right. Good good tripel.

A great unfiltered Belgian triple with exceptional low-key character.  Great color.  A little tame compared to other triples, but still excellent.  Great nose with subtle floral notes with hints of fruit and herbs.  Great yeast sediments (when theres stuff floating around inside it tells me its going to be aromatic and complex  this one is just what you might expect from an artisanal brasserie).
Sampled at the mondial de la bière de Montréal 2006.  Nice tripple.  golden color.  Nice flowers aroma.  Nice finish, a bit fruity and bitter.  Great.

Hazy yellow hue, with a frothy white head, with good lacing, yeasty, bready dough nose, with citrus fruits fruitiness, hint of spiciness and a faint floral hops in the aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a yeasty, zesty citrus fruits accent of lemons, grapefruits, pale malt, hint of floral hops, leading towards a lingering floral hops bitterness finish.

Quite an enjoyable tripel here. Enjoyed this one with my two best buddies after we did a photo shoot of some beautiful women in bikinis for a layout in a beer magazine. Not sure if it was the women that made this better, but somehow nearly nude, beautiful women somehow make beer taste better. But I digress. The aroma was tropical fruit like with banannas, pineapple juice and some yeastiness. Appearance was hazy orange. Velvety soft on the palate. Some hops, some tropical fruit, light bubblegum and some alcohol burn made this an enjoyable one. Very nice.

Bottle sampled with Beerded_one. Pours hazy orange\gold with a large lasting white head. Aroma of citrus, fruit, yeast, belgian spices, and sweet malts. Flavor is smooth, sweet, yeast, citrus, fruit noted, and a hoppy presence in the finish. Good body, good brew.

Bottle... Hazy, golden ale with a large, frothy, white head. Good retention. Fruity, yeasty nose with citrus, bread, mild spice and light alcohol. Tangy, warming flavor with generous hops. Lightly sweet; medium bitter. Medium-bodied with lively carbonation. Finishes spicy and a bit warming. Not my thing, but not at all bad.

From tap. Delirium cafe, Brussel. Hazy light golden beer with a white head. Smells very malty with some spicy and fruity notes. Tastes very simular: lots of malt, some citrus-zest and some coriander in a very good balance. Finishes sweet, a bit sourrish and sticky but not cloying.  Lovely brew.

Aroma:citrus fruit...
Appearance:very hazy hazy orange,small chunk of yeast,big white head...
Flavor:Light spicy and citrus,yeast,light bitterness...

Bottle.  Pours a light orange color with thin, persistent head.  Smell is hint of fruity yeast and taste is some sweetness and a little spiciness as well.  Nice mouthfeel.  Alcohol creeps up on you.  A very good tripel.
Aroma dolce, maltato, speziato (coriandolo e altro), fruttato e con evidenti note di lieviti. Gusto maltato, con un rivestimento piccante e retrogusto leggermente amaro. Lalcol e bene mascherato.

75 cl bottle. Beautiful orange colour with a big and lacing white head. Sweet and fruity aroma with some yeasty spiciness and a hint of coriander? Sweet malty flavours, gradually countered by yeasty dryness, ending on a dry note. Some fruitiness and pepper flavours. Full body, rather soft. Well-made, but not fantastic.
Bottle. Hazy golden colour with a white head. Fruity aroma with some spicy hints. Sweet malty flavor with hints of fruits and spices. Also some hoppy hints. Sweet spicy finish with some bitterness.

Bottle.
Hazy golden coloured with a huge white head.
Aroma of fruits, spices and hops.
Sweet flavour of fruits, spices and hops.
Good tripel !

Bottle.  Fruity coriander yeasty aroma.  Triple stereotype flavor.  Medium palate, spicy.  Semi translucent with right full head and lace.  Overall unmemorable but quite quaffable (isnt that the definition of the mid 3 range for me?)

750 ml capped bottle, undated, from Bello Vino in Ann Arbor, MI (Dec 2005).  Cellar temperature sampling in a Chouffe tulip.  The gorgeous snowy meringue head spatters thick gouts of lacing in the glass as it slowly descends from its glorious height to rest more comfortably atop its luminous spun-gold body....the vapors wafting out are noticeable across the room as light flowery sweetness; on closer inspection the nose discovers sharp sour bread, honey, an ever-so-light touch of butterscotch, and baked apples, glorious.....the tongue struggles to compete in its raptures with its loftier brother but fails, coming up only with lightly alcoholic sugar cookies immersed in thick pils malt, a touch of coriander sprinkled atop the rich mixture and a sour, long finish with a slightly cottony texture....going down, the last pleasures are reserved for the throat, which is happy enough but hardly overjoyed by the sticky liqueurish goodness, buoyed by an herb-infested ocean of grains....the mind in sum is a bit disappointed, the entrance was so majestic and the dance itself and recessional, though not pedestrian, surely earthbound.  A noble effort, not quite with the makings of royalty.

Draught @ Delirium Café, Bruxelles: Golden coloured. Unclear. Dense off white head. Wheaty nose. Coriander, yeast and sweetness. Flavour is yeasty, light spiced and has some fruitsweetness. Alcohol is notable. Is quite smooth but a little thin bodied. Ends on sweet and spiced note.

Bottle. Hazy golden-bronze color with a nice white head. Fruity, grassy aroma with some dull malt. Herbal, banana, yeasty, fruity flavor (lemon and apricot). Complex. Flavor lingers in the back of the mouth and finishes dry. Theres a nice flowery/herbal quality to it.

A very tasty belgian ale. As a frequently note in my beers, the crazy thick sweetness of some belgians turns me off, but this one works well. Call me picky. Regardless, I have no complaints about this beer. Actually suprised this isnt higher rated, but i guess a mellow belgian beer doesnt get much attention.

750ml bottle.  Sweet, flowery aroma, some honey and doughy yeast apparent, along with lighter touches of perfume, leafy, herbal hop, peach, white grape and light, grainy malts.  Deep golden amber color, clear, with a lasting, frothy white head and strands of lacing coating the glass.  Flavor profile is rather mellow for a beer of this strength, sweet and lightly fruity to start, some light citrus noted, thereafter seeing an influx of spicy hop flavor and bitterness that carries through to the finish, which also features some light, peppery alcohol notes, gentle acidity and dusty yeast.  Mouthfeel is smooth, warming and light, body is medium-full.  Enjoyable.

Hazy gold/light bronze. Creamy, off white head. Nice lacing. Aroma- sunscreen, rich malt, spices, sugar, floral hops. Lost points for the sunscreen. Flavor is a balance of sweet/spicy/sour. Rich malt, crisp floral hops, spices, yeast, alcohol. Finish and aftertaste are dry, alcoholic, yeasty. Full/medium, balanced body. Very nice, a bit unorthodox tripel.

Slighty spicy..very grassy aroma. Has hints of lemon zest. Cloudy yellow/gold color with a lovely white head that is exceptionally creamy looking like a lemon meringue. Fore is yeasty, creamy and malty. Tastes a bit like a white cake with heavy cream added and a tad of vanilla extract. But sadly other than a vaguley banana tinged note there isnt very much int he way of other flavors and it just comes off as a a really good, but highly one dimensional offering.

pours a cloudy golden color. aroma is slightly yeasty and spicy. taste is much lighter than i would like, some citrus and banana and other fruity flavors. lots of carbination. not a bad, but nothing special. not enough flavor for an 9 dollar beer.

Hazy golden color with a large foamy white head. Yeasty, fruity aroma (banana and peach). Some sweet malts, wheat (banana) and yeasty flavors. Dries out towards the finish, a little bit dusty with a spicy hop finish.

Bottle provided by and shared with tpkenned.  Semi-translucent, opulent and magnifying yellow with yeasties swimming about.  Creamy, fuzzy white head, beautiful vellum lace and an icy recession to wrap up the appearance portion.  Curt, husky aroma.  Evident pils malt, coriander, tin cans, sweet candied maize, ragweed and wet dog.  Calming lemon rind flavor joins coriander and pollen.  Straight forward starchy muskiness.  Lemon-herbed baguettes transition to vanilla and crystallized sugar over Lemonheads.  Not much effervescence, and generally a quick moving stream that loses steam near the end.  Well disguised alcohol, finishing with pepper, poppyseeds and limeade.  An honorable triple.

Hoppy, creamy peppery aroma. Malty, but not too sweet. Full bodied. Creamy, peppery flavor with hints of cardemom and anis. Throughout a hoppiness that becomes almost oily in the aftertaste. A worthy beer to close the year 2005.

a hazy orange body with medium head...great aroma, and is of floral notes, sugars, spice, heavy in lemon, and has some sort of a wit backbone to it....honey, lemon, yeast, spice, and sugars for flavor...nice palate

This bottled brew poured a large sized head of frothy fine to medium sized mostly lasting white colored bubbles that left behind a fair lacing.  The body contained average carbonation, was hazy and yellow orange in color.  Its aroma contained notes of floral malty mild coriander .  Its mouth feel is initially tingly with a  mild vinous palate and a biting fruity aftertaste.  Its flavor contained floral apricot fruit coriander  notes.
Cloudy light amber color. Nice malty and spicy aroma. Very spicy taste, a bit woody and corky, good malt, balanced. A good Triple.
Pours with an orange body topped by a medium thick head with a good amount of lacing.  Its sweet and floral with a touch of orange, a little spice and a touch of malt.  Medium bodied and smooth.

Draught, at Delirium.
Golden with large white head, mostly diminishing, ok lacings. Aroma moderate malty (citrus), light hoppy and yeasty. Flavor moderate sweet and bitter, long duration. Medium body, oily, normal carbonated. It is served to cold, so it was first sharp turning into smoothnes.
Hazy pale yellow, thick white diminishing head. Fruity, citric hoppy nose. Thick mouthfeel. Refreshing flavour with a great bitterness. Some notes of apple in finish.
Dont remember a whole lot of the details of this brew, but it was very solid.

750ml from Pabobcat. Pours a light orange color with a quickly receding white foamy head. Nose is very fresh smelling. Light hopps, some yeastyness, hint of honey and biscuit. Taste features some more light hops, citrusy orange and more honey.

Pours with a thin but lasting head, light glowing orange, mostly clear. Aroma has a dry, musty funkiness. Slight citrus with just hints of oak, pretty nice nose. Taste starts with some wheaty grains, subdued fruitiness with just a touch of bitter hops. Bready. Balanced, hidden alcohol. Mild candi sugar. Very smooth palate, incredibly easy to drink. Impressive for a style I dont like that much.

Draught at Delirium Cafe, Gothenburg, Sweden.
Orange, firm white head.
Grassy aroma with pomerance.
Yeasty and sweet flavour. A bit thin and metallic.
Somewhat hazy golden, nice white head. Yeasty wheat aroma, some hay, citrus and maybe some banana. Yeasty wheat flavor, grassy and rather hoppy with fruity notes.

Bottled. Sampled at Delirum Café, Göteborg. 
Golden style colour, big creamy head. Citrusy, pale malty nose, is it Maris Otter malt? Fairly big mouthfeel.  Refreshing, pleasantly laid-back sweetish and light bitter. Good beer.

Bottled.  Pours murky light copper in color with a big white head that fades leaving a thick lacing on the glass.  Aromas of bananas, clove, yeast, pears, paper and dust (?).  Flavors seems a bit watery and astringent (it coats my tongue).  HOWEVER.  The underlying flavors hint at what this bottle may have been or it could have possibly been.  Fruitiness galore with a bit of sourness.   Alcohol is barely perceivable.  I hope to retry this and rerate soon.

Poured from a bottle. Lovely aroma. Very fruity and malty with hints of summer fruits such as bananas, apricots, peaches, and pineapple. Lots of yeast in the flavor that contradicts the fruitiness. This is very good and sort of strange for a tripel in that it has some peppery spices and a strange aftertaste. The tropical fruitiness of this beer really does it for me though. Tripels are becoming one of my favorite styles.

Poperinge had a bottle open on his flight back from Belgium so we had to drink as soon as it was unpacked. Obviously somewhat unsettled. Cloudy orange. Light but lasting head. Smells like a very good wheat with banana and yeast. Full flavour of orange, banana and yeast.

A Mes rate:
A very high quality tripel. Quite dark for a tripel. Rather cloudy with a decent thin head that lasted very well. Apricot and slight malt in the nose. Flavour is similar but with some peach in there too. Peach? I dont even like peach! Sweet and tangy. This is damn fine stuff. Finish is long, starting with marzipan and gradually going bitter. I am not the biggest fan of tripels but I reckon this is top drawer stuff.

(Bottle 75 cl) Hazy amber colour with a small, creamy head. Aroma is malty with notes of yeast. Flavour comes with sweet malt and typical ale notes of fruit. Dry, lightly bitter finish. A pleasant drink. 160905

When your best girl friend is puking int he bathroom after her bachlorette party you have to drink something to pass the early morning hours--the Rulles was much to grand for this calling but a welcome respite from the american canned beers and shots of the nights activities.  Seemed to have more alcohol than posted, full of flavor, warm bodied, sweet finish, a relished treasured drinkable friend with an inviting label that I think I spoke to.
user_location: Middle of no where, Ohio, USA

text:
750ml. bottle. Hazy golden/orange color with a large white head. Aroma is fruity
(peaches), spicy(pepper, coriander) and yeasty. Flavor was pretty mild, more saison-like than a tripel.  It had the same fruity/spicy flavor that the aroma indicated, but was kind of dull and watery.
This poured cloudy gold with good head. Spice and earth and yeast notes in the nose. taste was great, some pepper, some malt and spice,  fruit and a bit of hop. Clean,dry clean finish.
Bottle. Again a deliciously hopped rulles. Fruit, apricot, yeast, bitter finish. More please.

If I hadnt opened the bottle myself, I would have thought this to be a light Belgian golden.  The 8.4% abv is well disguised, too.  It pours a hazy, cloudy golden body alive with the swirly bits, yeast all over the place.  The foamy head does has good retention and does some masterful lacing.  The aroma is a stright-arrow citric smell, perhaps tangerine, with a touch of floral hops.  The taste is sharp and acidic, some malt, to be sure, but predominantly a tart citric flavor.  The finish is sour and a bit sticky.  Strange tripel.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Wine & Spirits, Downers Grove, IL<font size=-1>

750ml bottle served in my NB worthy glass: Hazed golden hue with a nice frothy head and very good lace. The aroma is quite different than expected with lots of spicy notes of coriander, anise, and herbs. Some fruity, barnyard, and phenolic esters as well. The taste is equally strange and not what I would expect in a tripel. Sure there is a sweet malt and candi sugar base, but there is also a moderate acidic and flowery nature than seems not to fit the style. I get some phenols on the palate as well. The finish sort of peters out and only leaves some lingering pepper and just a touch of orange rind to remind you of what you just finished. That said, I do enjoy the flavor of this offering as a whole. The feel is fizzy and lively but not really refreshing either, once again not very Tripel like. There are some alcohol notes as well well into the bottle tasting. It is more Biere de Garde or even a winter Saison than Tripel in my opinion. In the end, it is an good brew to try and next time I will approach it more like the styles I wrote above and not expect a abbey beer.

Bottle. Large white head that was mostly lasting and contained fine-small sized bubbles, excellent lacing, yeasty, cloudy, carbonated, and a yellow gold hue. Aroma was malty, sweet and spices. Flavor was malty and spicy. Mouthfeel was tingly. Medium body. Nicely done and well worth a try IMMHO.

75 cl Bottle. Golden unclear colour with a nice creamy head. Good aroma of spices and hints of yeast. Wonderful flavour of spice and ends up with a good mouthful and a great aftertaste of some alcohol and hops.

Pours a hazy golden with a light sticky head. Aroma is heavily spiced with nutmeg and coriander being very prevelant. The flavor is equally heavy with spice and adds some yeastiness, and minor band-aid flavors. The body is med. The finih is short with the exception of some of the spices coating the tongue. Remember, if you can pick it out, youve used too much.

Cloudy orange, nice head that faded away slowly.  Built up quite a head in the bottle also.  Aroma was sweet candy and apricots.  Bit of nuttiness emerged as it warmed.  Flavors matched overall, although as it warmed a faint trace of moldy hay emerged as well.  Not bad by any means, but just didnt do anything for me.  Probably better than my numbers indicate, but I just couldnt justify raising any of them.

Labelled tripel, but kinda saisonish. Cloudy golden, large foaming head.  Enticing aroma, one that invites repeated sniffing.  Perhaps some coriander or others spice, honeyed malts, light phenols, overall fairly complex nose. Somewhat sweet up front, giving way to a light banana-ish phenolic middle.  Finish is herbal and spicy, with lingering notes of possible black pepper or coriander. Semi-dry to dry. Smooth and quite drinkable.
Poured cloudy yellowish orange with a fizzy off-white head.  Citrus nose.  Taste is malty sweetness, ctirusy hops and blended with a touch of alcohol.  Dry finish.  Nicely done.

pours light orange with a somewhat creamy white head. Aroma is spicy and sharp to the typical Belgian triple style. Taste is spicy orange, clove and other spices. Creamy mouthfeel somewhat comes through on the end.  Alcohol taste is also very present in this beer as well. Sit on it for a year maybe? This beer is good now, possible great later
Spicy nose with citrus. Hazy, orange coloured with a lasting, medium head. Taste is sweet, spicy, yeasty and citric. Smooth palate. Quite a good brew.

750 ml bottle.  Pours a nice slightly hazy gold with a decetn head and lace.  Aroma is more spicy and phenolic compared to some other tripels at the tasting  (Dulle Teve, Westmalle, Alllagash, St Bernardus, Golden Monkey & Karmeliet).   Flavor is moderately sweet, but balanced out with a good amount of earthy and spicy hops along with the phenolics and spices.  Finishes a little light and dry, but overall pretty smooth.

Very good, but a disappointment given all the praise Ive heard for this beer. Aromaless, with malty herbal flavour. Id like to compare this side by side with Guldenberg. The Rulles Blond seemed to me to be a greater achievement than this.

On tap at Eulogy Belgian Tavern. Pale yellow with a thin head and good lace. Relatively low carbonation. Light candi sugar and caramel aroma with some alcohol. Flowery, caramel flavor. A bit thin in body. Some noticable hops and bitterness. Alcohol apparent.

750 ml green bottle with no cork just a cap. Pours a deep hazy bright golden orange with a huge white frothy lasting head that leaves a sticky lace in my glass. Fruity and spicy cardboard aromas. Fruity buttery lemon and spicy yeasty flavors. Full bodied with lively carbonation and a crisp mouthfeel, finishes spicy and kind of sweet, alcohol is hardly noticed, a great triple
Draught. Orange cloudy. Fruity citrus nose. Sweet yeasty finish. Banana flavour. An average tripel.

on tap at the Spuyten Duyvil, Brooklyn NYC.  this one was on the house because I bought a box of their namesake lambic.  color is yellow gold, clear.  head is white and creamy, lasts long.  aroma is candi sugar, honey, lemongrass, white rum.  flavor is juicy like golden raisins, estery malt, tart wheat, and a little dry spicy hop.  some white rum hints are in the flavor, but this finishes clean.  biere always tastes better when its free!

Bottle. Classy stuff. Very warming and smooth. Sweet, wheaty estery fruit, with some light bretty characters, some orangey yeastyness. Sweetish and full bodied, with a very round mouthfeel. Some warming alcohol in the finish, but it helps balance the beer.

On draught at Redbones, June 2005.  Very hazy gold and light copper toned beer, with fine bubbles rising and a medium-sized white head, lightly creamy, well-retained with ample lacing.  Aroma is very spicy!  Rustic, farmy, hay-like hops add a zesty, pleasant spiciness, while light honey and grains make their way in.  Dry apricot and nectarine notes, some brief hints of tangerine and a dry, dusty yeastiness.  Flavor is moderately sweet, with good malt-extraction, plenty of spicy hops, though not terribly bitter.  Light hints of sour wheat on the end, coriander, delicious yeastiness and a full-on grass flavor lingering.  Mouthfeel was spot on in my sample, miniscule bubbles provide an invigorating, yet low carbonation, while the malt provides ample body, with no thinning.  Alcohol is not noted.  Baked wheat bread, honey and light nectarines/tangerines linger, with some dry herbs.
Hazy gold with a beige head. Brilliant farmyardy grainy aroma. Some slight funk too. Sweet grainy start with some wheaty notes. Alcohol very well disguised. Nice stuff
This was a nice tripel, but not extraordinary, by any means.  Flavor was bready and yeasty with some fruit notes.  Nice color and head, but a somewhat thin nose.

750 mL capped bottle: modest, ivory head that never truly dies.  Bready banana laced aroma with hints of coriander, honeycomb, mud caked hops and distinct grassy notes.  Close to intense, lively carbonation that is greatly soothing after a couple of long daysSoft gelatin and lightly toasted potato bread flavours give way to a thick yeasty mouth feel and tart esters.  Finishes with a long dry earthy bitterness and hints of lemon rind citrus.  A wonderful start to what promises to be an exiting beer weekend
Draught. Slightly fruity aroma. Cloudy golden colour. Semi-fruity flavour. Good mouthfeel. Not very highly carbonated. Aftertaste is a little sweet with a hint of tea.
This golden tripel-style poured with a slight white head. The initial flavor is full with a carbonated mouth feel and a slightly bitter finish. Overall, a nice tripel.
(draft) A fairly standard tasting tripel. Perhaps a little more citrus than Id prefer, but very drinkable.

Hazy golden body with a fluffy, white head that leaves thick sheets of heavy lace.  A nice, subtle aroma of clove, honey, orange peel, wheat bread, earthy hops, a little coriander, bananas and some lemon grass.  The body is crisp and effervescent with excellent carbonation.  The flavor is well crafted and fairly balanced.  The fruity esters and spices are the definite draw to the beer with the mild, slightly tart wheat bread and yeasty character lightly in the background.  The alcohol is well hidden, giving the slightest hint of warmth at the very end.  The warmth combines with dry, hoppy bitterness for an elegant finish.  One of the triples Ive enjoyed most of late--a tasty beer.
Golden colour with a dense off white head. Fruity and yeasty aroma with hints of spices. Fruity and light citric flavor, hoppy and dry bitter finish.
UPDATED: JUN 7, 2005 This was a rather standard Tripel. A bit of pepper and fruit (citrus) coming through on this one.  Had it on tap at Monks Cafe in Philadelphia.

Bright gold with a hazy orange core.  Nose fruity, bit spicy, but incredibly perfumey, very redolent.  Significantly less spicy than I expected, some yeastiness there, bit bready.  Some hops at the end, loads of perfume again, vaguely burns the inside of the mouth.  Quite fruity.  Best part of the drinking experience is the mouthfeel, simply an amazing palate.  Very creamy and rich, stunningly velvety.  Palate-wise, reminds me of the Fantome Ete I recently had, lovely, sticky fullness to it.

Light, lemon appearance.  Sugary, pear nose.  Yeast, alcohol, some cooke, and dough flavors.  Balanced with a citrus, orange peel flavor.  Some white pepper.  Active on the tongue.  This is solid, but the flavors could stand out more.  Tends to lose its dimensions after some time.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2006 Complex, floral, perfumey aroma offers pepper, lavender, orange blossom, mild sulfur, a hint of soap and strong biscuity malts.  Opaque yellow-tan with decent and lasting cover of white head that leaves excellent lacing.  Sugary, yeasty, tropical fruit flavours with green, leafy, citrus-pine hops and a mild bitterness that takes the edge off.  Medium body with fair carbonation.  Bottle enjoyed with beerbuzzmontreal, MartinT, Olivier_MTL, Rastacouere and Yowie.

The Lure:A soft Spalt-y, piney and peppery hop pillow on which is sprinkled some orange zest. Simple dreams ensue.

The Festivities:Piney hops rise proudly above the bitter yeast beach. Fluffy waves tropically crash on the back of the palate, decreasing the level of seriousness of the flavors.

Transcendence:A northern summer sun is a vivifying refreshment.

Pours a hazy orange color with a thin white head. It has an aroma of yeast, pepper and citrus. The flavor is the same, yeast, pepper and citrus. Light to medium body, creamy texture, moderate carbonation. Very good, the peppery flavor adds a very interesting dimension to this tripel.

Extreme stickiness of the foam make up a marvellous mountainous white head to cover the cloudy golden hue. Typical honey malt, almost toffeeish in its sweetness is nicely balanced by the extreme yeastiness and strong hop complexity. Sappy hop overtones procure a pineapple sensation that reminds of a sunny summer day. Alcohol is present, but mellow and blending well with the higher than average bitterness. Nice mouthfeel works well with the citrusy profile. Very smooth and creamy texture through a softer than velvet carbonation.
(750ml bottle)  Pours a cloudy maize body with a large egg-white head.  Aroma of florals, grass, cheese, horse blanket, and mustiness.  Spicy yeast flavor with a soft mouthfeel.

Fruity apricot , peach,  tangerine aroma with  some caramel. Orange hazy appeartaance. Spritzy mouthfeel. Fruity peach , melon , apricot flavor with some sweet malt and  mild hop bitterness with some warming alcohol.. Good fruit , malt and hop balance.

75cl bottle.  This bottle was excited to be opened, pushing some of that reluctant to flocculate Bastogne yeast into our glasses...foamy, blotchy head drops to a thin covering, but leaves nice lace.  Aroma is tremendous...the Bastogne & Amarillos mingle very nicely, creating the illusion that a bowl full of ripe peaches, oranges, apricots, & pears drenched in orange blossom honey sits in front of me...Lovely.  Drinks with restrained maltiness & still loaded w/ that wonderful ripe fruit character...light body, but full enough...bitterness just barely shows up, but the body is light enough that it doesnt need much to get a balance.  Real nice beer.

Cloudy orange with a frothy beige head.  Aroma was spice, citrus, grass, straw.  Medium body, lively carbonation, sparkly mouthfeel.  Flavor was spiced oranges with malty sweetness.  Not bad but nothing special.

So, when I got this bottle out of the fiidge I gave it a couple turnes upside down to get the yeast off the bottom.  Big mistake, even after an hour and half before I opened it, it foamed up like a volcano.  Amazingly after I poured out some of it, it calmed down, didnt even give me much head in the glass.  However, it looks mighty pretty not; golden orange color with some speckles floating throughout.  Aroma is a slightly skunky sweet malt scent, with some light fruit notes of citrus and orange.  Flavor is a smooth malt and fruity sweetness that is very drinkable.

Big bottle while sitting outside at N3rd for the first time this season.  Cloudy orange brew, no head, lots of fizz.  Aroma and upfront flavors of orange and vanilla?  Dont detect any added spice - it all comes from the yeast.  Very reminiscent of a well-made homebrew:  a bit sweet  kind of like the yeast ran out of gas and didnt ferment all the way - residual malt and candi sugar.

Wow the aroma is big and blasts out of the glass as the beer is poured. Hazy golden-amber body topped by a dense to rocky off-white head. Glass lace is excellent. Looks outstanding. THe aroma is loaded with citurs and freshly cut grass. Some sweetness (hiney?) lives in there also.  The flavor is definitely honey, some bread, lots of hoppiness all throughout, and some pepper in the finish. Quite  nice. Medium full body, soft carbonation. Very pleasant. Interesting bottle artwork also.
Pour a nice light gold. Hints of citrus and sugar. Very easy to drink for a triple. Love the label!

Yeasty and spicy with some seet cnady and citrus. A nice hazy dark golden colour with a sweet fresh flavour. Not sure if it is honey or floral notes as well, and then the citrus yeastiness again too. Lingers for a while too - nice.
clody gold, white head.  yeasty, biscuity, peppery aroma.  a bit of green apple and honey in the flavour with yeast, spice and alcohol.  lots of carbo.  not bad.

Bottle at Fall Beerfest In Toronto 2004.  Orange/amber in colour.  Aroma was yeasty, grassy, with some spice and citrus.  Flavour was of orange citrus, floral hops, yeast and malt.  Medium body, high carbonation.  Finishes with a medium dry bitterness.  I would like to try this one again someday.

Bottled. Hazy orange, dense head. Grassy and very orangey aroma. Sweet with soft, fresh, lively mouthfeel. Really hoppy. Dry, bitter finish with notes of licorice and lemon. An excellent beer with concentrated flavours.
Pours a golden hazy hue with a small white head with decent lacing.  Aromas of spice, slight yeastiness and a little citrus.  Flavors of the same.

Tasted in San Jose.  Sample is 750ml bottle of sheer goodness.  Omh.  Obtained from PlumpJacks in Noe, San Fran.  Appearance is golden and slightly hazy, with a thin white head. Aroma has a yeasty presence.  Flavour is sweet, slightly malty with a spicy and floral finish.

The yellowish golden hazy body seemed to have a glow coming from the center of it and was topped by a thick head and excellent lacing.  What a beauty - its centerfold material!  Aroma was sweet malt and spices along with some yeastyness and some citrus fruits.  Taste was nice - well balanced, sweet and a little bit lemony tart with a nice dry finish.  I thought this went really well with the plate of cheeses that we were munching on.

poured into a trappist to reveal a murky orange body with yeast floaties.typical white tripel head.smells almost like corona with a lime in it,along with belgian yeast.the flavor was well balanced and contained lemon,yeast,candy,and spices.this is a pretty average tripel.
Amarillo hops in the nose with a nice balance of yeasty spice. Bananas and herbal notes with a very light acidic tartness. Easy drinking session triple. If that were smart at all.

freed from the bottle, this is an attractive ale, lovely orange hue, gushing carbonation, lush, large head, fluffy white.
Aroma, wondrous spice, tantalizing citric flavor, outsized yeast...seems the very picture of the biere de garde style. quite arousing.
Taste: plays easily on the palate, smooth and tasty, yum...big citric fruit, substantial spice...all in a very nice example of the style. Big mouthfeel, extremely drinkable, medium bodied, with a long, fruity, lemony, spicy finish. 
I can easily recommend this one, but it doesnt unseat any of the giants of the style.
Draft - Nice golden color, lacey white head, Silky smooth, yeasty and fruity - bananna, citrus.

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2007 Poured a hazy orange color with a small, off white head, that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma reminiscent of Chimay White.  Lots of musty citrus, light banana, and yeast in the aroma.  Taste of spicy hoppiness, citrus fruits, melon, dry yeast, and a touch of alcohol in the finish.  Solid, straight-forward tripel.

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2010 (Bottled, 0.75l) Dark orange color with a medium, quite tight and lacy head. Dryish, even slightly sour, very fruity aroma with grassy hops. Medium-sour, slightly sugary, fruity flavor with bready-honeyish malt. ABV well hidden. Medium-bodied palate with quite high, but balanced carbonation. A nice and balanced, sourish tripel with some saisony dryness.
Pours a cloudy orange with a big frothy white head with thick creamy lacing.  Spicy, hoppy, and citrus in flavor Nice creamy texture with a smooth finish.  Very tasty triple. Thanks Dewbrewer!
bottle at dougshoemakers, golden yellow in color, minimal white head, aroma of yeast and alcohol, slightly dry and raisiny

Bottle. Pours a ruby splashed gold with lots of minute particle suspended in it. Aroma is floral and yeasty with a nice spice and a light fruit note. Taste is spicy and fruity with a nice splash of yeast. Very flavorful. Light alcohol notes and a mild sweetness throughout. Body is medium with a moderate carbonation feel. Finishes with more spice and fruit notes. More sweetened malts as well. The sweetness delicately balances the yeast and floral notes. Nice tripel!

Dry, close to dusty. A bit of fennel spiciness, sharp, but then thin, watery, and surprisingly so. A bit of pepper and a bit appley fruit. Nice, but I thought it was going to be fuller. Very nice looking - quintessential even in its soft gold, of the earth color.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: Large white head, great retention with gobulers of laceing left behind. A hazy blond hued ale. Spicey, peppery nose. Light/medium body. Fruity notes on the palate, hints of melons, black pepper and crusty bread. Dry, spicey finish.

Tosa Tasting. Hazy golden color with some fish food and a taller white head. Rose buds and pale malt aromas are full and forward. Flavors are of light peach and fruity in a perfume kind of way. Similar to Duvel but quite a bit more fruity, almost too much so. The aroma really helps this one.

ap: a cloudy golden color with a full white head.. the bottle blew a buble when opened
ar: hints of rose bud, grass, sweetness.. the smell is bold and incredible
pa: lightly carbonated, a bit light, fairly creamy
fl: sweet light fruits that I cant seem to pick apart.. odd aftertaste 
ovr: another beer that smelled better than it tasted not bad though
thanks to John for this one

Appearance:  Cloudy.  nice head.  Brassy color.  Aroma:  Flowers.  Saffron?  I think I got the yeast shot; a bit skunky.  Perfume.  Palate: Carbonation is good.  Good mouthfeel.  Flavor:  Light bread?  Herbal.  Moderate sweetness. Not bad, but not the best.

Shared at the Tosa Tasting courtesy of JPDIPSO: Hazy bronze golden color with a frothy lightly lacing white head.  Fresh European hoppy aroma has a subtle caramel Belgian malty sweetness and hints of strawberries.  Body is amazingly lacking the sweetness that the aroma told of.  Instead it has more of a dry earthiness and a floral finish with some bready yeastiness.  An interesting triple with a great aroma and mediocre body.  Thanks John for sharing!

Cracked open at MrFactos Tosa tasting, brought by JPDIPSO.  Cloudy orange body, medium off-white head.  Nice perfumey aroma with herbs, flower petals, and plenty of spice, combining for a sort of potpourri-in-a-bottle effect.  The flavor wasnt quite as compelling, with sweet honey, rotting fruit and white grape juice balanced by spices (pepper), flower petals, and a touch of honey.  Yeasty with a crackery finish.  The aroma was the best part of this solid beer.
Pours hazy gold/yhellow. Aroma is bannana, apples and fruit snacks. FLavor is astringent, bananas and lemons. Thanks to JpDipso for this one!

Medium golden, nice lacing.  Ripe melon aroma, screaming bastogne yeast.  Touch of grass.  Sweet smelling, estery.  Mellow flavor, more esters.  Sweet, but not too thick on the tongue.  Flavor is a touch disappointing compared to the attractive aroma, but quite nice.

Cloudy yellow/golden with frothy head. Light spices, pepper, perhaps nutmeg.  Not super-frothy palate, but a lively aroma and fairly easy drinking.  A winner. (2004 Christmas Party, my #2, groups #1)
This Abbey Triple pours large frothy head, beneath amber ale .Aroma:  Rather sweet, some aromatic hopps, and some dark spice. Medium thick, plenty of yeasty feel sweet malts.

Aroma of yeast, pear and malt, cloudy apricot, with a tiny white head. Flavour is mostly candied malt, medium bodied. Pretty good.

 Thanks IPFreely for bringing this!
Bottle.  Golden color with a white foamy head.  Candy, bubblegum, pepper, banana and spices.  A nice surprise.  Christmas Party 2004 ranked 3/15 (mine) and 1/15 (group).
My ability to take detailed notes was pretty much gone by this point in the evening. All I have for this one is "hazy golden colour, nice Belgian ale". [Toronto Christmas Party 04]

Draft: Another cloudy, golden yellow colored beer, quite pleasing, with a pleasant aroma of sugar, herbs, citrus, and honey, flavor is semi-sweet, with some lemon and yeast tones. finished slightly bitter
Slightly cloudy pale gold w/ white head. Yeasty, fruity, peppery aroma. Soft, chewy feel. Flavour is yeasty & malty w/ notes of vanilla, citrus, & spice.

strong tasty yeast. Sweet with citrus fruit, honeyish from yeast, some sugar, vanilla, other fruit. Bit of hop, smooth, tad of bitter dry finish. Satisfying.

Thank you Doug Shoemaker, for your private stock from Chesters, at your Great Tasting.

A very standard triple. Yeasty, light spice, some alcohol, light pale malts. Lots of carbonation, not prickly but not far off from it. Medium bodied, alcohol lets you know its there, but isnt overwhelming by any means.
Had this one in Bastogne. Cloudy golden coloured, thick head. Fruity aroma with wheat. Smooth flavour, very refreshing. I wouldnt have guessed the 8.4% ABV, not during drinking it at least...

Golden body with a small fluffy white head and excellent lacing. Sweet slightly alcoholic aroma. Flavour is nice, dry and sweet at different times. Bit light on the body. Worth a re-rate with a larger glass to myself. Thanks TimDoug.

Thanks to whoever brought this to the Toronto Christmas Party 04.  This is the point where I pretty much lost the ability to write.  I do seem to have noted something about a goat but Im not quite sure what that means...
Cloudy golden color, thick orange golden head. Aroma of banana, wheat, spices. Spicy taste, some alcohol, bit wheat. More fruity and creamy triple, nicely balanced.

A 750 mL bottle, not sure of the vintage. A very deep lighter gold coloring with a huge white head. Just like most tripels. Aroma is peach brandy, with some notes of bananas and herbs. Taste has peaches and a nice spicy note in the finish. Some nutmeg with citrus and black pepper. A nice creamy and rather syrupy mouthfeel. A solid, but slightly thin tripel.

(750ml bottle) Cloudy goldy body topped by large rocky off-white head.  Aroma is medium sweet, honey, pepper, lemon, herbal.  Taste is moderately sweet, orange/lemon, some herbal, pepper, light banana.  Finishes with medium alcohol warming.  Creamy medium-full body.

750 ml. green champagne bottle. No freshness date seen. Capped, but not corked. Poured out a hazy, light orange / caramel color. It had a huge frothy, white, meringue like head that held on for dear life. It left a more than generous lacing down the sides of my Chimay chalice. (What else do you serve a Belgian in?) Aromas are of orange creme candies, hint of citrus, fresh cut Timothy grass, slight fruitiness as well.
No typical Belgian funk, and that is a welcome relief. Tastes are of citrus, malts, some vanilla and caramels, definite melon flavors as well. No pepper, no banana, and no cloves make this the cleanest tasting triple Ive had so far. Carbonation level is high, but correct for the style. Not much in the hops dept. Subdued hop aromas & flavors. Thick, rich mouthfeel. Creamy & smooth in texture. Finishes very well balanced. A top notch triple.
Shared big bottle at Monks in Philly. Nice triple. This was rather smooth for a triple. Good malt bite to it.

Thin, creamy foam on top.  Great carbonation that keeps the thin head the duration.  Slightly spicey (pepper) and fruity aroma with a hint of roasted corn.  Color is a cloudy light orange.  Slightly fizzy in the mouth.  Bit more pepper and spices.   Some yeast and light malt.  Little hops with a slightly tart aftertaste.  A decent triple but not a great example of the style.  Very smooth and drinkable though.

UPDATED: NOV 14, 2005 Tap @ Blind Tiger. Cloudy peach color with aroma of sweet fruits, cantelope, banana and vanilla. Taste is almost equally sweet with some pepper, malt and dough. Just a tad sweet without pronounced hoppiness, mellowed with the right amount of earthiness. Medium bodied and really drinkable.

Orange.  Fruity (banana, peach, pineapple) aroma with a touch of toffee, vanilla, clove, caramel and a hint of aromatic hops (herbs, flowers).  Upon tasting, this is one of the best triples I have ever had.  Malty, full and creamy.  Notes of passion fruits, caramel corn and the perfect sweetness.  Lovely stuff.
Bottle at the Belgian Beerfest. Bright orange with medium white head. Sweet vanilla aroma, orange. Well balanced medium body, vanilla and malty. Alcohol well-hidden. A standard but solid trippel.

UPDATED: OCT 12, 2005 Head is initially average sized, frothy, white, mostly lasting. Body is hazy dark yellow, bottle conditioned. Aroma is moderately malty (toasted grain), lightly hoppy (lemon, flowers), lightly yeasty (cobwebs), with notes of pepper, clove, pineapple. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, moderately acidic, moderately bitter. Medium to full body, watery/velvety texture, lively carbonation, lightly alcoholic.  Very well hidden alcohol is cool...otherwise, this just doesnt quite excite me to the tune of a 4+.  Its well made, clean, has great balance...all the right makings of a good tripel, but its holding back on me a little in both nose and flavor. Second review, this time with my own bottle in a quiet setting (first was at a Dr. Bill tasting), but same score as before.
Hazy golden color, light sweet fruity malty aroma and taste, full body, long dry finish.
This is a ok Abbey Triple.  Light, malty, and fruity (citric) flavor.  Finishes clean, fresh, and crisp.
750 ml bottle. Golden in color with a white head. Hoppy. Fruity banana aroma. Malty flavor. Sweet flavor with lsome bitterness.  Decent beer.

UPDATED: MAR 11, 2005 10.31.04  750ml bottle.  Dingy orange-rusty-gold color with lots and lots of bits is not very attractive.  Massive white and rocky head leaves mucho lace.  Very light aromas and flavors of pale fruits, apricot, old white grapes, peppery spice, scone.  A bit too watery on the palate.  More like a German flavor to me than Belgian, whatever that means; I never would have pegged this as a triple if I hadnt read the bottle.   I got a surplus of tea notes, too.  Disappointing as a tripel but subtle and beautiful in its delicate floral honeysuckle and orange blossom notes.  Good beer, bummer of a tripel.

Bottle at Copenhagen Beermarathon 2004: Golden, with a white head. Aroma is spice, yeast, and surprisingly hoppy. Taste is malty, spicy, slightly fruity with some bitterness from the hops. are medium long bitter aftertaste.

750 ml bottle. Golden with a white head and floaties. Aroma of fruity banana and what I pick out as hops, most likely Saaz. Flavor is malty, with a seemingly present hop flavor. Some sweetness and alcohol with a low bitterness. IA touch yeasty. Decent brew and I like the hop touch.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: Bottle pours cloudy yellow, large pillowy white head, sticky lacing, with very subtle carbonation.   Lots of fine sediment floating about as well.   Citrus & floral notes in the aroma.   Fairly bready/yeasty up front, not as sweet as Id expect either.   Spices seem somewhat dull.   Medium body, wheaty mouthfeel.   Finishes fairly decent, but the spices seem to be somewhat dull.   Not as crisp as I would have hoped.   Decent, but nothing exceptional.

UPDATED: MAR 17, 2009 Bottle  Amber-blond, hazy body.  Rocky, off-white, dense head.  Strong, complex aroma of hops, citrus, caramel, crispy malts, ...  Well balanced flavour.  Heavily bitter, lightly sweet flavour with citrus popping up in the end and staying there.  The aroma is very nice, but the flavour cant compete with it.
Hazy orange in color.  Light bodied, zesty mouthfeel.  Slight fruit ester in the aroma. As triples go this one is very simple, yet refreshing and easy to drink.
Blond beer with a small head. The aroma dominating herbal. The taste is light bitter. It is a very typical triple tasting beer but well balanced.

Peach-coloured, ochre head reducing itself to a half centimetre. Herbal, spicey (ginger, laurel, garden weeds) nose. Taste: this is what you call Band-aid? It certainly has a flavour as from a would liner - mint/camphor perhaps. Having said that, this taste is quite mild. Rest is more typical tripel. Dry-touch of candi sugar, and yeasty. Ending a bit more fruity/citrussy. Well bodied. Reasonable tripel. More surprising than most.

cloudy dark orange colour with a big dense head, honey and grapefruit aroma, fresh, smooth and slightly oily with a medium to full body, it has a long and pleasant vinous, cellar-like aftertaste with strong reminiscence of honey
